awd_abstract_narration:
This project centers on algebraic differential equations and model theory. Differential equations are at the heart of modern mathematics and its applications in other sciences. Model theory is a part of mathematical logic in which objects known as definable sets are studied. The notion of a definable set is flexible, changing as one works in different mathematical settings. In the area of differential algebra, definable sets are closely linked with differential equations, providing a connection between the two subjects. This project plans to exploit that link to advance the knowledge of both fields. The project also seeks applications in other areas of mathematics, primarily number theory.

This research project addresses problems in the model theory of fields with operators. First, the investigator will generalize his work on the differential algebra of the j-function to understand the differential equations satisfied by analytic covering maps associated with various Shimura varieties. This line of work is expected to have number theoretic consequences related to special-point conjectures as it did in the case of modular curves. The project will also investigate several finiteness results in differential algebra; this line of work is expected to have consequences on effective bounds in number theory and in computational differential algebra. The project aims to develop various aspects of the model theory of supersimple and superstable groups as a generalization of recent work in differential algebraic and difference algebraic groups. The project will investigate the classification of disintegrated strongly minimal sets in differentially closed fields. This work seeks to answer a fundamental question about differential equations: what are the possible structures given by the differential algebraic relations between solutions to a fixed differential equation? Finally, this project aims to adapt and generalize results from algebraic foliations and vector fields for application in differential algebraic geometry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project centered around problems of foundational interest in the model theory of fields and differential algebraic geometry and its generalizations as well as problems in pure model theory. The lines of research pursued in this project have found application in number theory and machine learning. 

The central goal of the project was to investigate, from a model theoretic and differential algebraic perspective, automorphic functions of subgroups of GL_2. This goal constituted a major generalization of the PI's work joint with Scanlon investigating the model theory of the j-function. Such automorphic functions are ubiquitous in number theory and numerous applications. Jointly with Nagloo and Casale, the PI achieved this goal, in the process answering an old classical open question of Painleve from 1895. The project also centered on investigating foundational questions about algebraic differential equations from the model theoretic perspective. This line of work resulted in new results on the effective definability of Kolchin polynomials, jount with Leon-Sanchez and Li. 

This project also resulted in several new results in pure model theory related to combinatorics, joint with Chase. These results have found application in several important models of machine learning. For instance, Chase and Freitag connect online learnability of a concept class to an important dividing line in model theory, stability. Freitag and Chase also proved new results in the area of query learning and characterized learnability by queries in several models by model theoretic notions. This connection opens up the possibility of the wide application of model theoretic techniques in learning theory. 

During the course of the project, the PI worked with five PhD students, one of whom completed their studies. The education of students through activities supported by this grant was central to the broader impacts of the project. One of the main activities supported by the grant, Midwest Model Theory Day ran four times with the support of the grant. 

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: James E Freitag
